info.game_comments:
2004 Power Players Week game 4.
From Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: The location of Washington, D.C. was actually chosen by G.W., & it's a nice little commute from this estate of his

(2, 1).clue: It was the nickname of comedian Richard Skelton

(3, 1).clue: Chris Elliot, Tim Meadows, Phil Hartman & Darrell Hammond have all played this 42nd president

(4, 1).clue: This potent potable's name comes from the Latin for juniper, which is used to flavor it

(6, 1).clue: Delivered November 19, 1863, it began, "Four score and seven years ago..."

(1, 2).clue: Rumor has it a former owner once let her dog wear this diamond; now it "springs eternal" at the Smithsonian

(2, 2).clue: Paul Bunyan's Babe was a giant ox of this color

(3, 2).clue: Chevy Chase was known for taking a tumble or two when playing this 38th president

(6, 2).clue: After slaying this giant, David cut off his head & took it with him to Jerusalem

(1, 3).clue: "Rome had... Anita Ekberg splashing in the Trevi Fountain; we got Wilbur Mills and Fanne Foxe" in this "Basin"

(2, 3).clue: Tom Clancy's first 2 novels had this color in their titles

(3, 3).clue: In 1976 Dan Aykroyd did his first televised impression of this presidential candidate

(6, 3).clue: Like, oh my God!  In the '80s this word mentioned in "Valley Girl" often preceded "to the max"

(2, 4).clue: It's the color mentioned in the title of the following

(3, 4).clue: Dana Carvey not only played Bush Sr. during the '92 race, he also played this independent Texan challenger

(6, 4).clue: In a word, it's the rock 'n' roll musical set at Rydell High School

(3, 5).clue: In a cartoon by Robert Smigel, Ford & Bush the First are among these title superheroes (now in paperback)

(6, 5).clue: This edible export from Holland comes in "wheels" that may weigh 25 pounds

(1, 1).clue: Of 1, 3, or 10 miles away, it's the farthest distance from which a polar bear can smell food

(2, 1).clue: Before taking her seat in the Senate, Dianne Feinstein was Mayor of this California city

(3, 1).clue: How ya gonna keep 'em down on the farm after they've heard this way the French pronounce their capital

(4, 1).clue: Mark Twain noted a striking difference between a cat & a lie: "A cat has only" this many "lives"

(5, 1).clue: This constellation features the twins Pollux & Castor

(6, 1).clue: The boss of Bond, James Bond

(1, 2).clue: About her possible entry into politics, the N.Y. Post ran the 1993 headline "Senator Yentl"

(2, 2).clue: Uta Pippig had a "run" of good luck winning this race in 1994, 1995 & 1996; Fatuma Roba won in 1997, '98 & '99

(3, 2).clue: If you have more than one French chateau, you don't pluralize chateau with S but with this letter

(4, 2).clue: Of the snowshoe, the golf shoe or the tennis shoe, the one that really is a breed of cat

(5, 2).clue: Sirius, the brightest point of Canis Major, that's Canis, people, is also called this star

(6, 2).clue: The only one that's on the musical scale

(1, 3).clue: The town of Derry is the setting of this author's "It" & "Insomnia"

(2, 3).clue: New York's Ithaca College awards a scholarship named for this NBC News anchor who died in a tragic auto accident in 1983

(4, 3).clue: Legend says that the Manx cat lost this feature by slipping into Noah's Ark just as the door was closing

(6, 3).clue: The hunt is on for Peter Lorre in this 1931 Fritz Lang film about a child murderer

(1, 4).clue: In 1876 this "Wild" West man was killed in the Dakota Territory holding aces & 8s, later known as a dead man's hand

(2, 4).clue: "Brooklyn Bridge" was one of the last of her NYC paintings before she moved permanently to New Mexico

(4, 4).clue: Gus the Cat lived in the Carytown book store in this Va. capital for 19 years before going to cat heaven in 2001

(1, 5).clue: He was "On the Road" in 1957 but found the final exit ramp in 1969

(0, 0).clue: Beginning an American tradition, in 1801 Aaron Burr's daughter Theodosia & her new husband honeymooned here
